irp:protocol.name: 48-NEC
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Like DecodeIR, we call a 48-NEC* signal without repeat "48-NEC".

irp:protocol.name: AdNotam
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Very similar to RC5, except AdNotam uses two start bits, and no toggle bit.

irp:protocol.name: Aiwa2
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Source: Dave Reed's program Teaser.

irp:protocol.name: Akord
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Protocol found in Akord HDMI switches. Similar to NEC1, but with different timing. See forum thread.

irp:protocol.name: Amino
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Amino equipment use both 37 and 56KHz, but the duration of the half-bit is always 268. Zaptor is a closely related protocol which for which the half-bit duration is 330.

irp:protocol.name: Anthem
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Anthem framing is very similar to NEC, and also uses 32 bits of data. However, the leadout is much shorter. The signal is sent at least 3 times.

irp:protocol.name: Anthem_relaxed
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Relaxed version of the Anthem protocol.

irp:protocol.name: Apple
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This protocol uses the same framing as NEC1. D is normally 238, with 224 while pairing, but also other values have been observed. C is a checksum, making the whole payload having even parity.

irp:protocol.name: Archer
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is not a robust protocol, so spurious decodes are likely.

irp:documentation.p: Protocol used by several manufacturers of 433MHz RF controlled switches, like Intertechno, Duewi, ELRO, KlikAanKlikUit, and the URC light control kit, and many other. Appears to be introduced by the Taiwanese firm ARC Technology. These codes correspond to switches with code wheels, having an "House number" ranging from "A" to "P", in the IRP above corresponding to D=1 up to 16 for "P". They also have an "Address", ranging from 1 to 16, corresponding to the parameter "S" in the IRP. Note that e.g. Intertechno makes switches "with code wheel" and "without code wheel", the latter having a much larger addressing space, and unfortunately cannot be controlled by the present protocol. F=0 is the power off command, F=1 the power on command. The power on command is also used for dimming, both up and down.
In some One for All remotes, for example the URC-7781, the setup codes 2200,2201,...,2215 correspond to this protocol, 2200 for house "A", up to 2215 for house "P".

irp:protocol.name: arctech-38
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Same as arctech, but with an IR-typical modulation.

irp:protocol.name: B&O
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: 455kHz protocol used by some Bang & Olufsen equipment. Forum thread.

irp:protocol.name: B&O repeat
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: From David Reed's program Teaser.

irp:protocol.name: Barco
irp:protocol.irp:documentation:
This protocol uses no modulation of the signal.
This is a moderately robust protocol, but spurious decodes are still possible.

irp:protocol.name: CanalSat
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: The repeat frames are not all identical. T toggles within a single signal, with T=0 for the start frame and T=1 for all repeats. The official name for CanalSat is "ruwido r-step".

irp:protocol.name: CanalSatLD
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: The official name for CanalSatLD is "ruwido r-step"

irp:protocol.name: Canon
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: IR protocol for many Canon cameras. With F=0 it triggers immediately, F=1 it triggers after a delay of approximately two seconds.

irp:protocol.name: Denon
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: A Denon signal has two halves, either one of which is enough to fully decode the information. When one half is seen it will be decoded as Denon{1} or Denon{2}. Denon, Denon{1} and Denon{2} all represent the same protocol when correct, but only Denon is robust.

irp:protocol.name: Denon-K
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Denon-K is the member of the Kaseikyo family with OEM_code1=84 and OEM_code2=50. It uses the same check byte rules as Panasonic protocol, but uses the data bits differently.

irp:protocol.name: Denon{1}
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: See Denon.

irp:protocol.name: Denon{2}
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: See Denon.

irp:protocol.name: Digivision
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: See GuangZhou, which has identical framing but with different bit definitions.

irp:protocol.name: DirecTV_3FG
irp:protocol.irp:documentation:
There are six variants of the DirecTV protocol, distinguished in RemoteMaster by the parameter "Parm" on the Setup page. The Parm value is shown in the Misc field of DecodeIR. The IRP notation above corresponds to the default Parm=3. The various Parm values correspond to three different frequencies (the 38k in the above) and two different lead-out times (the -50 in the above). The corresponding values are:
Parm=0 : 40k, -15
Parm=1 : 40k, -50
Parm=2 : 38k, -15
Parm=3 : 38k, -50
Parm=4 : 57k, -15
Parm=5 : 57k, -50

irp:protocol.name: DirecTV_P0
irp:protocol.irp:documentation:
There are six variants of the DirecTV protocol, distinguished in RemoteMaster by the parameter "Parm" on the Setup page. The Parm value is shown in the Misc field of DecodeIR. The IRP notation above corresponds to the default Parm=3. The various Parm values correspond to three different frequencies (the 38k in the above) and two different lead-out times (the -50 in the above). The corresponding values are:
Parm=0 : 40k, -15
Parm=1 : 40k, -50
Parm=2 : 38k, -15
Parm=3 : 38k, -50
Parm=4 : 57k, -15
Parm=5 : 57k, -50

irp:protocol.name: DirecTV_P1
irp:protocol.irp:documentation:
There are six variants of the DirecTV protocol, distinguished in RemoteMaster by the parameter "Parm" on the Setup page. The Parm value is shown in the Misc field of DecodeIR. The IRP notation above corresponds to the default Parm=3. The various Parm values correspond to three different frequencies (the 38k in the above) and two different lead-out times (the -50 in the above). The corresponding values are:
Parm=0 : 40k, -15
Parm=1 : 40k, -50
Parm=2 : 38k, -15
Parm=3 : 38k, -50
Parm=4 : 57k, -15
Parm=5 : 57k, -50

irp:protocol.name: DirecTV_P2
irp:protocol.irp:documentation:
There are six variants of the DirecTV protocol, distinguished in RemoteMaster by the parameter "Parm" on the Setup page. The Parm value is shown in the Misc field of DecodeIR. The IRP notation above corresponds to the default Parm=3. The various Parm values correspond to three different frequencies (the 38k in the above) and two different lead-out times (the -50 in the above). The corresponding values are:
Parm=0 : 40k, -15
Parm=1 : 40k, -50
Parm=2 : 38k, -15
Parm=3 : 38k, -50
Parm=4 : 57k, -15
Parm=5 : 57k, -50

irp:protocol.name: DirecTV_P3
irp:protocol.irp:documentation:
There are six variants of the DirecTV protocol, distinguished in RemoteMaster by the parameter "Parm" on the Setup page. The Parm value is shown in the Misc field of DecodeIR. The IRP notation above corresponds to the default Parm=3. The various Parm values correspond to three different frequencies (the 38k in the above) and two different lead-out times (the -50 in the above). The corresponding values are:
Parm=0 : 40k, -15
Parm=1 : 40k, -50
Parm=2 : 38k, -15
Parm=3 : 38k, -50
Parm=4 : 57k, -15
Parm=5 : 57k, -50

irp:protocol.name: DirecTV_P4
irp:protocol.irp:documentation:
There are six variants of the DirecTV protocol, distinguished in RemoteMaster by the parameter "Parm" on the Setup page. The Parm value is shown in the Misc field of DecodeIR. The IRP notation above corresponds to the default Parm=3. The various Parm values correspond to three different frequencies (the 38k in the above) and two different lead-out times (the -50 in the above). The corresponding values are:
Parm=0 : 40k, -15
Parm=1 : 40k, -50
Parm=2 : 38k, -15
Parm=3 : 38k, -50
Parm=4 : 57k, -15
Parm=5 : 57k, -50

irp:protocol.name: DirecTV_P5
irp:protocol.irp:documentation:
There are six variants of the DirecTV protocol, distinguished in RemoteMaster by the parameter "Parm" on the Setup page. The Parm value is shown in the Misc field of DecodeIR. The IRP notation above corresponds to the default Parm=3. The various Parm values correspond to three different frequencies (the 38k in the above) and two different lead-out times (the -50 in the above). The corresponding values are:
Parm=0 : 40k, -15
Parm=1 : 40k, -50
Parm=2 : 38k, -15
Parm=3 : 38k, -50
Parm=4 : 57k, -15
Parm=5 : 57k, -50

irp:protocol.name: Dish_Network
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is not a robust protocol, so spurious decodes are likely. See this thread for a discussion.

irp:protocol.name: Dishplayer
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is not a robust protocol, so spurious decodes are likely.

irp:protocol.name: Dyson
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This protocol is used by Dyson fan heaters. T is a toggle but its range of values may depend on the Dyson model. For example, the AM05 cycles T through 0,1,2 leaving the value 3 unused. The Dyson2 protocol differs in having a longer lead-out between the two full frames. It is used in the AM05 for the Power button. For signals with no ditto repeat frames to be decoded by IrpTransmogrifier, Repeat Finder must be turned off.

irp:protocol.name: Dyson2
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: The Dyson protocol is used by Dyson fan heaters. T is a toggle but its range of values may depend on the Dyson model. For example, the AM05 cycles T through 0,1,2 leaving the value 3 unused. The Dyson2 protocol differs in having a longer lead-out between the two full frames. It is used in the AM05 for the Power button. For signals with no ditto repeat frames to be decoded by IrpTransmogrifier, Repeat Finder must be turned off.

irp:protocol.name: Dyson_relaxed
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Relaxed version of the Dyson and Dyson2 protocols, which tests only the first frame. A signal may decode as Dyson_relaxed because (a) the signal is incomplete, or (b) the capture hardware cannot report large lead-out values, or (c) the signal has no ditto repeat frames and Repeat Finder has squashed it.

irp:protocol.name: Elan
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: See the JP1-forum thread.

irp:protocol.name: Elunevision
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Elunevision Luna motorized projector screen remote. Posting on Lirc mailing list.

irp:protocol.name: entone
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: A special case of the RC6-M-56 protocol, used in the Entone Amulet. See this forum thread.

irp:protocol.name: F12
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Old version of the F12 specification.

irp:protocol.name: F12-0
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Taken from DecodeIR, case H=0.

irp:protocol.name: F12-1
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Taken from DecodeIR, case H=1.

irp:protocol.name: F12_relaxed
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Relaxed version of the F12 specification.

irp:protocol.name: F32
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: The meaning of the 32 bits of data is unknown, and the assignment to D, S, F, and E is arbitrary.

irp:protocol.name: Fujitsu
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Fujitsu is the member of the Kaseikyo family with OEM_code1=20 and OEM_code2=99. There is no checksum, so the risk of an incorrect decode is much higher than in other Kaseikyo protocols.

irp:protocol.name: Fujitsu_Aircon
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Protocol for Fujitsu inverter air conditioning. RemoteCentral thread. This version is a re-parametrization of 3FG's version, allowing for decoding.

irp:protocol.name: Fujitsu_Aircon_old
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Protocol for Fujitsu inverter air conditioning. RemoteCentral thread.

irp:protocol.name: G.I.4DTV
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is a moderately robust protocol, but spurious decodes are still possible. Unit (device) numbers from 0 to 7 are supported. The check sum C is a Hamming Code, which can correct single bit errors. D:1:2 is encoded in the checksum. See forum thread.

irp:protocol.name: G.I.4DTV_relaxed
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Relaxed version of G.I.4DTV the checksum is not checked but considered a parameter.

irp:protocol.name: GI RG
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is a moderately robust protocol, but spurious decodes are still possible. Typical usage is the GI/Next Level/Motorola RC2x00 series.

irp:protocol.name: Grundig16
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: These are two variants of the same protocol, differing only in frequency. The IRP notation is corrected from previous versions of this document, to make it consistent with DecodeIR.

irp:protocol.name: Grundig16-30
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: See Grundig16

irp:documentation.p: Protocol for Disney's Glow with the Show Hat/Ears, see forum thread. Unfortunately, the IRP engine cannot compute the CRC, but the user has to enter it as a parameter.
The known commands are, together with their F and CRC values, as follows:

irp:protocol.name: GXB
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Decoder for a nonstandard Xbox remote.

irp:protocol.name: Humax 4Phase
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Forum thread.

irp:protocol.name: InterVideo RC-201
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Used by a remote marked as InterVideo RC-201 that is paired with a USB HID receiver simply marked as RC-201. Exact carrier frequency not known.

irp:protocol.name: IODATAn
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is potentially a class of protocols distinguished by values of n, x and y with n = 0..15 and x, y = 0..127. If x and y are both zero, they are omitted. The only known example is IODATA1.

irp:protocol.name: Jerrold
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is not a robust protocol, so spurious decodes are likely.

irp:protocol.name: JVC
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: JVC{2} indicates a JVC signal from which the lead-in is missing. The JVC protocol has lead-in on only the first frame, so it is quite easy to have it missing from a learned signal. So when JVC{2} is correct, it means the same as JVC. It is very similar in structure and timing to Mitsubishi protocol. JVC documentation.

irp:protocol.name: JVC-48
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: JVC-48 is the member of the Kaseikyo family with OEM_code1=3 and OEM_code2=31.

irp:protocol.name: JVC_squashed
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is a version of the JVC protocol for signals that has been too much reduced ("squashed") by the repeat finder.

irp:protocol.name: JVC{2}
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: See JVC.

irp:protocol.name: Kaseikyo
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is the nominal form of the Kaseikyo protocol.

irp:protocol.name: Kaseikyo56
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Kaseikyo56 is a lengthened version of the Kaseikyo family of protocols. It has the same OEM codes indicating the same manufacturers as Kaseikyo, and it has the same variation (by manufacturer) in check byte and other details as Kaseikyo.

irp:protocol.name: Kathrein
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This protocol signals repeats by the use of dittos. It is unusual in that the ditto frame carries part of the signal data, specifically F. Similar to Logitech, but both decodes give the same device number and OBC.

irp:protocol.name: Keeprite A/C
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: An air conditioning protocol, see this thread.

irp:protocol.name: Logitech
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This protocol is used with Logitech's PS3 adapter. Similar to Kathrein.

irp:protocol.name: Lutron
irp:protocol.irp:documentation:
From the DecodeIR documentation:
This is an unusual protocol in that an 8-bit device code and 8-bit OBC are encoded in a 24-bit error-correcting code as the X of the IRP notation. This is constructed as follows. First two parity bits are appended to the 16 data bits to give even parity for the two sets of 9 bits taken alternately. The resulting 18-bit sequence is then treated as 6 octal digits (0-7) expressed in 3-bit binary code. These are then re-coded in the 3-bit Gray code (also called, more descriptively, the reflected-binary code) with a parity bit to give odd parity, so giving 6 4-bit groups treated as a single 24-bit sequence. The whole thing allows any single-bit error in transmission to be identified and corrected.

irp:protocol.name: Matsui
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is not a robust protocol, so spurious decodes are likely.

irp:protocol.name: MCE
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: MCE is a member of the RC6 family. Technically it is RC6-6-32 with the standard toggle bit zero, with the OEM1 field equal to 128, and with a nonstandard (for the RC6 family) toggle bit added.

irp:protocol.name: MCIR-2-kbd
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: A RC6-ish keyboard IR protocol used by the Microsoft Remote Keyboard for Windows Media Center Edition, referred to by Microsoft's Windows Media Center remote specification docs as "an internal protocol called MCIR-2". See HiFi-Remote thread and Linux media driver.

irp:protocol.name: MCIR-2-mouse
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: A RC6-ish mouse IR protocol used by the Microsoft Remote Keyboard for Windows Media Center Edition, referred to by Microsoft's Windows Media Center remote specification docs as "an internal protocol called MCIR-2". See HiFi-Remote thread and Linux media driver.

irp:protocol.name: Metz19
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: The toggle bit T is inverted each time a new button press occurs.

irp:protocol.name: Mitsubishi
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is not a robust protocol, so spurious decodes are likely. It is also very similar in structure and timing to JVC{2} protocol.

irp:protocol.name: Mitsubishi-K
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Mitsubishi-K is the member of the Kaseikyo family with OEM_code1=35 and OEM_code2=203.

irp:protocol.name: NEC
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Inspired by DecodeIR, we call a NEC signal without repeat "NEC". This decode normally indicates an incomplete learn.

irp:protocol.name: NEC-f16
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: A relaxed form (but used in some real devices) of the NEC protocol. Byte 3 and byte 4 are independent.

irp:protocol.name: NEC-Shirriff
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Like NEC1 but without repeat, just one large parameter, and msb bit order, no ending silence, and undetermined payload length. This is how NEC protocols are referred to in the Arduino IRremote project, originated by Ken Shirriff.

irp:protocol.name: NEC-Shirriff-32
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: The NEC-Shirriff protocol with payload length set to 32, making it viable for decoding.

irp:protocol.name: NEC1
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: The most commonly used version of the NEC protocol, repeating with dittos. Tutorial.

irp:protocol.name: NEC1-f16
irp:protocol.irp:documentation:
A relaxed form (but used in some real devices) of the NEC1 protocol. Byte 3 and byte 4 are independent. NEC1-Yamaha is a special case of this, in which bytes 3 and 4 are related but in a different manner than in a standard NEC1 signal. The NEC1 standard is that byte 4 is the complement of byte 3. The relationship in an NEC1-Yamaha signal is determined by a style parameter with values Y1, Y2 and Y3 as follows:
Y1: Only bits 0-6 are complemented.
Y2: Only bits 1-7 are complemented.
Y3: Only bits 1-6 are complemented.

irp:protocol.name: NEC1-rnc
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Variant of the NEC1 protocol with the checksum in byte 4 different (complement F and reverse the nibbles).

irp:protocol.name: NEC1-y1
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Variant of the NEC1 protocol with the checksum in byte 4 different (complement all of F except the MSB).

irp:protocol.name: NEC1-y2
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Variant of the NEC1 protocol with the checksum in byte 4 different (complement all of F except the LSB).

irp:protocol.name: NEC1-y3
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Variant of the NEC1 protocol with the checksum in byte 4 different (complement all of F except MSB and LSB).

irp:protocol.name: NEC2
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: A variant of the NEC protocol, that repeats by repeating the whole intro sequence. Pioneer is distinguished from NEC2 only by frequency.

irp:protocol.name: NEC2-f16
irp:protocol.irp:documentation:
A relaxed form (but used in some real devices) of the NEC2 protocol. Byte 3 and byte 4 are independent. NEC2-Yamaha is a special case of this, in which bytes 3 and 4 are related but in a different manner than in a standard NEC2 signal. The NEC2 standard is that byte 4 is the complement of byte 3. The relationship in an NEC2-Yamaha signal is determined by a style parameter with values Y1, Y2 and Y3 as follows:
Y1: Only bits 0-6 are complemented.
Y2: Only bits 1-7 are complemented.
Y3: Only bits 1-6 are complemented.

irp:protocol.name: NECx1-f16
irp:protocol.irp:documentation:
A relaxed form (but used in some real devices) of the NECx1 protocol. Byte 3 and byte 4 are independent. NECx1-Yamaha is a special case of this, in which bytes 3 and 4 are related but in a different manner than in a standard NECx1 signal. The NECx1 standard is that byte 4 is the complement of byte 3. The relationship in an NECx1-Yamaha signal is determined by a style parameter with values Y1, Y2 and Y3 as follows:
Y1: Only bits 0-6 are complemented.
Y2: Only bits 1-7 are complemented.
Y3: Only bits 1-6 are complemented.

irp:protocol.name: NECx2-f16
irp:protocol.irp:documentation:
A relaxed form (but used in some real devices) of the NECx2 protocol. Byte 3 and byte 4 are independent. NECx2-Yamaha is a special case of this, in which bytes 3 and 4 are related but in a different manner than in a standard NECx2 signal. The NECx2 standard is that byte 4 is the complement of byte 3. The relationship in an NECx2-Yamaha signal is determined by a style parameter with values Y1, Y2 and Y3 as follows:
Y1: Only bits 0-6 are complemented.
Y2: Only bits 1-7 are complemented.
Y3: Only bits 1-6 are complemented.

irp:protocol.name: Nokia32
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: The Nokia32 protocol is one variation of the RCMM 1.5 protocol developed by Philips. RCMM refers to X as "System" and to D:2,S:4:4 as "Customer". The parameters have been taken from SB-projects.

irp:protocol.name: Nokia32_endframe
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: A version of the Nokia32 protocol that sets T=0 except for the last frame, which has T=1.

irp:protocol.name: NRC17
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Taken from John Fine's contribution (fixed), modified for the setup here.

irp:protocol.name: Ortek_NEClike
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: See this thread.

irp:protocol.name: OrtekMCE
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: The repeat sequences are not all identical. P is a position code: 0 for the start frame of a repeat sequence, 2 for the end frame and 1 for all frames in between. C is a checksum, 3 more than the number of 1 bits in D, P, F together.

irp:protocol.name: OrtekMCE_relaxed
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is a relaxed version of the OrtekMCE protocol, in that it lacks the intro sequence.

irp:protocol.name: PaceMSS
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is a moderately robust protocol, but spurious decodes are still possible.

irp:protocol.name: Panasonic
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Panasonic protocol is the most commonly seen member of the Kaseikyo family.

irp:protocol.name: pid-0083
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This protocol is a very limited design. We have seen it used only in the UEI setup code TV/0159, which is for some TVs brand named Fisher, Sanyo and Sears. It is not likely that any other code set uses this protocol. So if you get a correct decode of pid-0083 you probably have a TV that can be controlled by the TV/0159 setup code.

irp:protocol.name: Pioneer
irp:protocol.irp:documentation:
Pioneer is distinguished from NEC2 only by frequency. So if your learning system does not learn frequency accurately, it won't accurately distinguish Pioneer from NEC2. All Pioneer signals should have a device number in the range 160 to 175 and no subdevice. No NEC2 signal should fit those rules. So you usually can determine whether the decision (by frequency) was wrong by checking the device numbers.
Many Pioneer commands are sent as combinations of two different Pioneer signals, see Pioneer-Mix.

irp:protocol.name: Pioneer-Mix
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Two-signal version of the Pioneer protocol. First sends the "normal" signal (parameters D0 and F0) as intro, then, as repeat, the one determined by D and F.

irp:protocol.name: Proton
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is not a robust protocol, so spurious decodes are likely.

irp:protocol.name: Proton-40
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is not a robust protocol, so spurious decodes are likely.

irp:protocol.name: RC5
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: In Philips' (the creator of the protocol) terminology, "D" is called "System" and "F" is called "Command". Tutorial.

irp:protocol.name: RC5x
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: In Philips' (the creator of the protocol) terminology, "D" is called "System", "S" is called "Command", and F is called "Data".

irp:protocol.name: RC6
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: RC6 is the name used for the first member of the RC6 family of protocols. Technically this is RC6-0-16. Tutorial.

irp:protocol.name: RC6-6-20
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: The executors for this protocol do not toggle T. This no-toggle version is commonly used in Sky and Sky+ remotes.

irp:protocol.name: RC6-M-24
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is a generic version of Replay that supports M values other than 6. The RC6-M-24 executor for this protocol supports both toggle and non-toggle behaviours for T.

irp:protocol.name: RC6-M-28
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: The executor for this protocol does not toggle T.

irp:protocol.name: RC6-M-32
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is the generic form for a decode of protocols in the RC6 family, restricted to 32 bits. Exceptions: RC6-0-16 is displayed as simply RC6, RC6-6-24 is displayed as Replay, and some RC6-6-32 which is displayed as MCE. The executor for this protocol supports both toggle and non-toggle behaviours for T.

irp:protocol.name: RC6-M-56
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is the "RC6-M-N protocol" made usable for the case of N=56.

irp:protocol.name: RCA
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: RCA and RCA(Old) are two very similar forms of RCA protocol which differ only in that RCA(Old) has an extended lead-in and a double-length ON pulse before the lead-out. They are so similar that most RCA devices will accept either. But some RCA devices only accept the one that really matches.

irp:protocol.name: RCA(Old)
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: See RCA.

irp:protocol.name: RCA-38
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: These are recently discovered variants of the RCA protocol. They differ from RCA and RCA(Old) only in the frequency, which is 38.7kHz instead of the standard 58kHz.

irp:protocol.name: RCA-38(Old)
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: See RCA-38.

irp:protocol.name: Replay
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Replay is a member of the RC6 family; technically it is RC6-6-24.

irp:protocol.name: Revox
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Revox uses no modulation.

irp:protocol.name: Roku
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This IR protocol is very similar to NEC2, except the repeat behavior is different. The second and additional frames of a repeating signal send the OBC + 128. Reference.

irp:protocol.name: Rs200
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This protocol is/was used by the so-called RS-200 RF (433MHz) controlled switches, that were sold by Conrad Electronics. There is a "house numbers" consisting of four digits, each in the range 1 to 4. These are called H1, H2, H3, and H4 in the IRP. There is also a "device address". Officially, it ranges from 1 to 4, however, at least on the hardware I (BM) tried, 5 can also be used and assigned to a receiver. Also, 6 was working, and in fact controlled the "group" consisting of all devices with address 1,...,5. For 7 and 8, no function has been verified. F=0 is the power on command, F=1 the power off command, and F=2 the power toggle command.

irp:protocol.name: RTI_Relay
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Protocol used by RTI RCM-4 Relay module, see this forum thread.

irp:protocol.name: RTI_Relay_alt
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Different parameterization of RTI_Relay.

irp:protocol.name: Sampo
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is a moderately robust protocol, but spurious decodes are still possible.

irp:protocol.name: Samsung-SMT-G
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Forum thread.

irp:protocol.name: Samsung20
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is a moderately robust protocol, but spurious decodes are still possible.

irp:protocol.name: Samsung36
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Reference.

irp:protocol.name: ScAtl-6
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: ScAtl-6 is distinguished from Emerson only by frequency. Most Scientific Atlanta cable tuners instead use the Panasonic_Old protocol.

irp:protocol.name: Sejin-1-38
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is the Sejin-1 version from DecodeIR, with the following substitutions: Dx -> D, Fx -> F, Fy -> S, L = 77. (Teaser uses a slightly different parameterization.)

irp:protocol.name: Sejin-1-56
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is the Sejin-1 version from DecodeIR, with the following substitutions: Dx -> D, Fx -> F, Fy -> S, L = 77. (Teaser uses a slightly different parameterization.)

irp:protocol.name: Sharp
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: A Sharp signal, which is almost identical to Denon, has two halves, either one of which is enough to fully decode the information. When one half is seen separate from the other, it will be decoded as Sharp{1} or Sharp{2} depending on which half is decoded. Sharp, Sharp{1} and Sharp{2} all represent the same protocol when they are correct, but only Sharp is robust.

irp:protocol.name: SharpDVD
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: SharpDVD is the member of the Kaseikyo family with OEM_code1=170 and OEM_code2=90. E=1 in all instances seen so far.

irp:protocol.name: Sharp{1}
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: See Sharp.

irp:protocol.name: Sharp{2}
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: See Sharp.

irp:protocol.name: SIM2
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Reference. In that document, there is a contradiction between the verbal description and the Pronto Hex code given. Here we follow the Pronto form, which is also consistent with DecodeIR.

irp:protocol.name: Solidtek16
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is a keyboard protocol. The make/break bit is decoded into the subdevice field.

irp:protocol.name: Somfy
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: F = 1 for UP or 2 for DOWN. D = 1, 2 or 3 for the three observed devices, or D = 0 to control all devices together.

irp:protocol.name: TCL_AC
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Protocol used by air conditioning devices by TCL and others. See this thread, this thread, and this thread.

irp:protocol.name: TDC-38
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: There are two variants of this protocol, with different frequencies but with the same number of carrier cycles in each burst, which makes the duration of a burst also differ. TDC-38 has a 38kHz carrier and is used by Danish TDC IPTV. TDC-56 has a 56.3kHz carrier and is used by Italian ALICE Home TV box. These implementations effectively use a 6-bit OBC as bit 0 of F is always the complement of bit 1, but there are other implementations which do not follow that pattern.

irp:protocol.name: TDC-56
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: There are two variants of this protocol, with different frequencies but with the same number of carrier cycles in each burst, which makes the duration of a burst also differ. TDC-38 has a 38kHz carrier and is used by Danish TDC IPTV. TDC-56 has a 56.3kHz carrier and is used by Italian ALICE Home TV box. These implementations effectively use a 6-bit OBC as bit 0 of F is always the complement of bit 1, but there are other implementations which do not follow that pattern.

irp:protocol.name: Teac-K
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Teac-K is the member of the Kaseikyo family with OEM_code1=67 and OEM_code2=83. Teac-K uses different repeat rules and a different check byte than other Kaseikyo protocols.

irp:protocol.name: Thomson
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is not a robust protocol, so spurious decodes are likely.

irp:protocol.name: Tivo unit=0
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Kludge protocol for compatibility with DecodeIR and irdb.

irp:protocol.name: Tivo unit=1
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Kludge protocol for compatibility with DecodeIR and irdb.

irp:protocol.name: Tivo unit=10
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Kludge protocol for compatibility with DecodeIR and irdb.

irp:protocol.name: Tivo unit=11
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Kludge protocol for compatibility with DecodeIR and irdb.

irp:protocol.name: Tivo unit=12
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Kludge protocol for compatibility with DecodeIR and irdb.

irp:protocol.name: Tivo unit=13
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Kludge protocol for compatibility with DecodeIR and irdb.

irp:protocol.name: Tivo unit=14
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Kludge protocol for compatibility with DecodeIR and irdb.

irp:protocol.name: Tivo unit=15
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Kludge protocol for compatibility with DecodeIR and irdb.

irp:protocol.name: Tivo unit=2
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Kludge protocol for compatibility with DecodeIR and irdb.

irp:protocol.name: Tivo unit=3
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Kludge protocol for compatibility with DecodeIR and irdb.

irp:protocol.name: Tivo unit=4
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Kludge protocol for compatibility with DecodeIR and irdb.

irp:protocol.name: Tivo unit=5
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Kludge protocol for compatibility with DecodeIR and irdb.

irp:protocol.name: Tivo unit=6
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Kludge protocol for compatibility with DecodeIR and irdb.

irp:protocol.name: Tivo unit=7
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Kludge protocol for compatibility with DecodeIR and irdb.

irp:protocol.name: Tivo unit=8
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Kludge protocol for compatibility with DecodeIR and irdb.

irp:protocol.name: Tivo unit=9
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Kludge protocol for compatibility with DecodeIR and irdb.

irp:protocol.name: Velleman
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Very similar to RECS80-0045, except on duration is longer.

irp:protocol.name: Velodyne
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Velodyne is a close relative of XMP.

irp:protocol.name: Viewstar
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This is not a robust protocol, so spurious decodes are likely.

irp:protocol.name: Whynter
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: From IRremote, see also this issue. "Tested with Whynter ARC-110WD."

irp:protocol.name: X10-command
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This protocol is used to send X10 command codes to an IR543 receiver or compatible device.

rm:deployment.rm:translator: Cmd=all off|all lights on|turn on|turn off|dim|brighten|all lights off|(reserved)| hail req|hail ack|preset dim|cmd11|cmd12|status is on|status is off|status req

irp:protocol.name: X10-device
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This protocol is used to send X10 device (unit) selection codes to an IR543 receiver or compatible device. Devices are numbered from 1 to 16.

irp:protocol.name: X10-house
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This protocol is used to send a house code to an IR543AH receiver or compatible device. More basic X10 receivers such as the IR543 do not accept the house code as an IR signal. The house code is a letter in the range A-P.

irp:protocol.name: X10.n
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: This protocol is a UEI version of the protocol used to send X10 device (unit) and command codes to an IR543 receiver or compatible device. This protocol sends a non-functional first frame that is ignored by the receiver before sending the true X10 signal. The true X10 signal is that of the X10-device and X10-command protocols. For receivers that accept the house code as an IR signal, the X10-house protocol is used to send that value.

irp:protocol.name: Xiaomi
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Protocol found in the Xiaomi Mi Box Streaming Android TV Device. Defined and described in this thread.

irp:protocol.name: XMP
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: DecodeIR documentation.

irp:protocol.name: Zaptor-36
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: T=0 for all frames except the last, T=1 for last frame, E is a checksum seed. A protocol so far seen only in the Motorola Zaptor.

irp:protocol.name: Zaptor-56
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: T=0 for all frames except the last, T=1 for last frame, E is a checksum seed. A protocol so far seen only in the Motorola Zaptor.

irp:protocol.name: Zenith
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: An unusual protocol, in that the number of bits in the function code is variable. There are also two lead-in styles, decoded as subdevice values 0 and 1. Style 1 aka "double-start" is usually used in TV's, other appliances use 0 aka "single start".

irp:protocol.name: Zenith5
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Special case of the Zenith protocol, with D = 5.

irp:protocol.name: Zenith6
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Special case of the Zenith protocol, with D = 6.

irp:protocol.name: Zenith7
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Special case of the Zenith protocol, with D = 7.

irp:protocol.name: Zenith8
irp:protocol.irp:documentation: Special case of the Zenith protocol, with D = 8.
